reg:regulation.reg:acttitle: Court Rules Act and Court of Appeal Act
reg:regulation.reg:title: Court of Appeal Rules

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In these rules:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Act means the Court of Appeal Act;
business day means a day on which the court registries are open to the public;
completion instructions means the instructions issued by the registrar for completion of documents;
document includes the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a photograph, film or sound recording;
any record of a permanent or semi-permanent character;
any information recorded or stored by means of any device;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: file, in relation to a document, means to file the document in a court registry in accordance with the requirements under these rules or any directives of the registrar issued under section 38 [directives in relation to filing] of the Act;
hearing date means the date set for a hearing;
inactive appeal list means the list of inactive appeals maintained by the registrar under Rule 49 (1);
intervener means a person who has been granted leave under Rule 61 [intervener status] to intervene in an appeal;
obtain a hearing date, in relation to an appeal or application, means to obtain from the registrar a hearing date for the appeal or application;
ordinary costs tariff means the tariff of ordinary costs set out in Schedule 1;
serve, in relation to a document, means to serve the document in accordance with these rules;
supporting affidavit means an affidavit that sets out any facts that a person intends to rely on at a hearing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In these rules, words and expressions that are not defined have the same meanings as in the Act.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If the time for doing an act under these rules falls or expires on a day other than a business day, the time is extended to the next business day.

bcl:part.bcl:text: How to File and Serve Documents

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: General requirements for filing and serving documents
bcl:section.bcl:text: Unless a contrary intention appears, if a rule in these rules requires a person to file and serve a document that relates to an appeal, the person must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file the document, and
serve on each party to the appeal a copy of the filed version of the document.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A notice of appeal must be served on a respondent by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: serving the respondent personally,
serving the respondent's lawyer of record in the court appealed from, or
serving the respondent in any other manner directed by a justice or the registrar.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A document, other than a notice of appeal, may be served on a party by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: serving the party personally,
serving the party's lawyer of record on an appeal,
if the party has filed a document containing an address for service,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: delivering the document to the party's address for service, or
sending the document to the party's email address for service, if any, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: serving the party in any other manner directed by a justice or the registrar.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A document required to be served under these rules on a person other than a party may be served in a manner set out in subrule (2).
A document transmitted for service by email or fax is deemed to be served as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the document is transmitted at or before 4 p.m. on a business day, the document is deemed to be served on that day;
if the document is transmitted at either of the following times, the document is deemed to be served on the next business day:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: after 4 p.m. on a business day;
any time on a day other than a business day.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Registrar directives â€” manner of filing documents
bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 38 [directives in relation to filing] of the Act, and without limiting the authority of the registrar under that section, the registrar may issue directives

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: requiring that any document under these rules be filed

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in either paper or electronic form, or
in both paper and electronic form, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: specifying the number of copies of a document that must be filed.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Steps at the Start of an Appeal

bcl:division.bcl:text: Bringing and Responding to an Appeal

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who wishes to appeal an order must do the following within the time limit set out in subruleÂ (2):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a notice of appeal in Form 1 that names as a respondent each person

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: who was a party to the proceedings in the court appealed from, and
whose interests could be affected by the relief sought in the notice;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: serve, in accordance with Rule 4 (1) [permitted methods of service], on each respondent named in the notice of appeal a copy of the filed notice of appeal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The time limit for filing and serving a notice of appeal of an order is the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: unless paragraph (b) applies, not more than 30 days after the order is pronounced;
if another enactment specifies a time limit within which the appeal must be commenced, that time limit.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: How to respond to a notice of appeal

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A respondent who is served a notice of appeal and who wishes to participate in the appeal must, not more than 10Â days after being served the notice of appeal, file and serve on the appellant a notice of appearance in FormÂ 2.
If a respondent who has been served a notice of appeal does not file a notice of appearance under this rule,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the respondent is presumed to take no position on the appeal, and
a party is not required to serve on the respondent any further documents related to the appeal, unless the court or a justice orders otherwise.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Bringing and Responding to a Cross Appeal

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: When to bring a cross appeal
bcl:section.bcl:text: A respondent may file a notice of cross appeal only if the respondent

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has filed a notice of appearance in Form 2,
is seeking to vary the order being appealed, and
is seeking relief from the court that is different from the relief sought by the appellant, as described in the notice of appeal.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: How to bring a cross appeal
bcl:section.bcl:text: To bring a cross appeal, a respondent must do the following not more than 15 days after being served a notice of appeal:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a notice of cross appeal in Form 3;
serve a copy of the filed notice of cross appeal

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: on each party, and
on any other respondent named in the notice of cross appeal.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: How to respond to a notice of cross appeal

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: To respond to a notice of cross appeal, a respondent referred to in Rule 9 (b) (ii) must file and serve a notice of appearance in Form 2 not more than 10 days after being served the notice of cross appeal.
If a respondent referred to in Rule 9 (b) (ii) does not file a notice of appearance under this rule,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the respondent is presumed to take no position on the cross appeal, and
a party is not required to serve on the respondent any further documents related to the cross appeal, unless the court or a justice orders otherwise.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Bringing and Responding to Applications for Leave to Appeal

bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of the definition of "limited appeal order" in section 1 of the Act, the following orders are prescribed as limited appeal orders:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order granting or refusing relief for which provision is made under any of the following Parts or rules of the Supreme Court Civil Rules:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: Rule 3-7 (22) [order for particulars];
Part 5 [Case Planning];
Part 7 [Procedures for Ascertaining Facts], other than Rule 7-7 (6) [application for order on admissions];
Rule 9-7 (11), (12), (17) or (18) [adjournment or dismissal, preliminary orders, orders, and right to vary or set aside order];
Part 10 [Property and Injunctions];
Part 11 [Experts];
Rule 12-2 [Trial Management Conference];
Rule 18-1 [Inquiries, Assessments and Accounts];
Rule 21-7 [Foreclosure and Cancellation];
Rule 22-1 (4) [evidence on an application];

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order granting or refusing relief for which provision is made under any of the following Parts or rules of the Supreme Court Family Rules:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: Rule 4-6 (3) [order for particulars];
Part 5 [Financial Disclosure], other than Rule 5-1 (28) (b) and (c) [relief];
Rule 7-1 [Judicial Case Conference];
Part 9 [Procedures for Obtaining Information and Documents], other than Rule 9-6 (6) [application for order on admissions];
Rule 10-3 (4) [evidence on an application];
Rule 11-3 (11), (12), (17) or (18) [adjournment or dismissal, preliminary orders, orders and right to vary or set aside order];
Part 12 [Property and Injunctions];
Part 13 [Court Ordered Reports and Expert Witnesses];
Rule 14-3 [Trial Management Conference];
Rule 18-1 [Inquiries, Assessments and Accounts];

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order granting or refusing interim relief under the Family Law Act or the Divorce Act (Canada);
an order granting or refusing an assessment of a family matter made under section 211 [orders respecting reports] of the Family Law Act;
an order granting or refusing an adjournment or an extension or a shortening of time;
an order in respect of costs or security for costs, if the only matter being appealed is in respect of costs or security for costs;
an order of a Supreme Court judge granting or refusing an appeal from an order referred to in any of paragraphs (a) to (f).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: When an application for leave to appeal is required
bcl:section.bcl:text: A party bringing an appeal or cross appeal must apply for leave to appeal if any of the following apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the order being appealed is a limited appeal order;
an enactment, other than the Act, requires leave from the court or a justice to appeal or cross appeal the order being appealed;
the party bringing the appeal or cross appeal does not know whether leave of the court is required to bring the appeal or cross appeal.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: How to apply for leave to appeal
bcl:section.bcl:text: A party who wishes to bring an application for leave to appeal must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file and serve a notice of application in Form 4 and an application book for leave to appeal prepared in accordance with the completion instructions not more than 30 days after filing the related notice of appeal or notice of cross appeal, as applicable, and
obtain a hearing date for the application that is at least 10 business days after the application for leave to appeal is filed and served.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: How to respond to an application for leave to appeal

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party who wishes to respond to an application for leave to appeal must file and serve a response book for leave to appeal at least 5Â business days before the application hearing date.
A response book for leave to appeal must be prepared in accordance with the completion instructions.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applications for leave that must be heard concurrently
bcl:section.bcl:text: Unless a justice or the registrar orders otherwise, if the appellant and one or more respondents apply for leave to appeal in relation to the same order, those applications must be heard at the same time.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Use of application book for leave to appeal in remainder of appeal
bcl:section.bcl:text: A justice may allow an application book for leave to appeal to stand as a substitute for one or more documents that may be filed in an appeal.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: How to appeal a subsequent related order after an appeal is brought

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this rule, subsequent related order, in relation to an order that is under appeal, means an order that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is made after the order that is under appeal, and
involves the same parties and the same cause or matter.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This rule applies to a party who is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an appellant, or
a respondent who brings a cross appeal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party may appeal a subsequent related order under this rule

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: before a notice of hearing of appeal is filed for the order that is under appeal, or
after a notice of hearing of appeal has been filed, if permitted by a justice or the registrar on application.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar may dispense with a requirement under DivisionÂ 1 of PartÂ 9 in an application referred to in subruleÂ (3)Â (b).
A party who appeals a subsequent related order under subruleÂ (3) must,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of an appellant, file an amended notice of appeal, or
in the case of a respondent who brings a cross appeal, file

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: file a notice of cross appeal, and
if the notice of cross appeal has already been filed, file an amended notice of cross appeal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party referred to in subrule (5) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: address the subsequent related order in the party's factum, or
if the factum has already been filed, file and serve an amended factum.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party who is required to file and serve an amended factum under subruleÂ (6)Â (b) must do so,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of an appeal under subrule (3) (a), before a notice of hearing of appeal is filed, unless otherwise directed by a justice or the registrar, and
in the case of an appeal under subrule (3) (b), within the time limit set by the justice or registrar.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless otherwise directed by a justice or the registrar, a party who is served an amended factum must file and serve an amended response factum not more than 15Â days after being served.
For the purposes of subrules (5) to (8),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amendments in an amended factum may address only the amendments made in the amended notice of appeal, and
the amendments in an amended response factum may address only the amendments made in the amended factum.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Rule 82 [amending filed documents] does not apply to an amended notice of appeal, amended factum or amended response factum that is filed under this rule.
For certainty, this rule does not affect a person's right to appeal a subsequent related order in accordance with DivisionsÂ 1 toÂ 3 of PartÂ 3.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Adding Additional Respondents to an Appeal

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Justice may add respondents to an appeal

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A justice may make an order under subrule (2), if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person was not named as a respondent in a notice of appeal or notice of cross appeal, and
the justice determines that the person has interests that could be affected by the relief sought in the appeal or cross appeal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On application by a person referred to in subruleÂ (1)Â (a), a justice, in the circumstances referred to in that subrule, may order that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person be added as a respondent to the appeal,
the notice of appeal or notice of cross appeal, as applicable, be amended to name the person as a respondent, and
the person be served the amended notice of appeal or notice of cross appeal, as applicable.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before filing a notice of application or any other document for the purposes of commencing an application under subruleÂ (2), a person who wishes to bring an application must obtain a hearing date for the application.
A person who wishes to bring an application under this rule must file and serve the following documents at least 5 business days before the application hearing date:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a notice of application in Form 4;
the person's supporting affidavits, if any;
the person's written argument, if any.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who is served a notice of application under this rule may, for the purposes of responding to the application, file and serve the following documents at least 2Â business days before the application hearing date:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person's supporting affidavits, if any;
the person's written argument, if any.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar may set the date, time and place for the hearing of an application under this rule.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Division, stay application means an application for a stay of proceedings or a stay of execution referred to in RuleÂ 20Â (1).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applying for a stay of proceedings or execution

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party may apply for a stay of proceedings or a stay of execution to put on hold a proceeding or a process of execution pending the outcome of an appeal.
A party may join a stay application with the party's application for leave to appeal in accordance with subruleÂ (4).

To bring a stay application, a party must file and serve a notice of application in FormÂ 4 and an application book prepared in accordance with the completion instructions at least 5Â business days before the application hearing date.
To join a stay application with an application for leave to appeal, a party must, instead of bringing an application for leave to appeal under Rule 13,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file and serve a notice of application in Form 4 and an application book for leave to appeal and stay prepared in accordance with the completion instructions not more than 30 days after filing the related notice of appeal or notice of cross appeal, as applicable, and
obtain a hearing date for the application that is at least 10 business days after the application for leave to appeal is filed and served.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party who wishes to respond to a stay application must do one of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a stay application that is not joined with an application for leave to appeal, file and serve a response book at least 2Â business days before the application hearing date;

in the case of a stay application that is joined with an application for leave to appeal, file and serve a response book for leave to appeal and stay at least 5Â business days before the application hearing date.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A response book under this rule must be prepared in accordance with the completion instructions.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Steps After an Appeal Is Brought

bcl:section.bcl:text: An appeal is brought for the purposes of these rules as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if leave to appeal is not required, when the appellant

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: files the notice of appeal, and
serves a copy of the filed notice of appeal on each respondent named in the notice of appeal;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if leave to appeal is required, when leave to appeal is granted.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Documents Filed to Ready an Appeal for Hearing

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An appellant must file and serve an appeal record

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: not more than 60 days after filing a notice of appeal, or
if leave to appeal is required, not more than 60 days after leave to appeal is granted.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An appeal record must be prepared in accordance with the completion instructions.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Transcripts of proceedings in court appealed from

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this rule, book of transcripts means a book of transcripts that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: includes the transcripts required under subrule (3), and
meets the requirements for transcripts set out in subrule (4).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An appellant must file and serve a book of transcripts

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: not more than 60 days after filing a notice of appeal, or
if leave to appeal is required, not more than 60 days after leave to appeal is granted.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless a justice or the registrar orders otherwise, a book of transcripts must contain the following from the proceedings under appeal:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: transcripts of all oral testimony, if any was given;
transcripts other than testimony, if they are necessary to resolve the issues under appeal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Transcripts that are filed in the court must be prepared

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by an official reporter from the official record of the court appealed from, and
in accordance with the British Columbia Court Transcription Manual.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar may dispense with a requirement under subrule (4).
Despite subrule (3), an appellant may exclude any portion of a transcript from a book of transcripts with the agreement of the other parties.
An appellant must file and serve an appellant's factum not more than 30 days after filing the appeal record.
A respondent must file and serve a respondent's factum not more than 30 days after being served an appellant's factum.
An appellant may reply to a respondent's factum by filing and serving an appellant's reply not more than 7Â days after being served the respondent's factum.
Documents filed under this rule must be prepared in accordance with the completion instructions.
In this rule:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: appeal book means a book that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: contains the evidence referred to in a party's factum, and
meets the requirements set out in subrule (4);

bcl:definition.bcl:text: joint appeal book means an appeal book prepared jointly by all the parties to an appeal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the appellant's factum refers to evidence, the appellant must file and serve an appeal book when the appellant files and serves that factum.
If the respondent's factum refers to evidence that is not included in the appellant's appeal book, the respondent must file and serve an appeal book when the respondent files and serves that factum.
An appeal book and joint appeal book must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be prepared in accordance with the completion instructions, and
include only as much evidence as is necessary to resolve the issues on appeal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subrules (2) and (3),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the parties may file a joint appeal book not more than 30 days after the respondent files the respondent's factum, and
filing a joint appeal book under paragraph (a) satisfies the requirement for a party to file and serve an appeal book.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the costs of an appeal are increased unduly by a party's failure to comply with subrule (4), a justice or the registrar may consider the party's failure to comply when awarding or assessing costs.
In this rule:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: book of authorities means a book that includes, subject to subrule (5),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: each authority referred to in a party's factum, and
each authority that a party intends to refer the court to at the hearing of an appeal;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: joint book of authorities means a book of authorities prepared jointly by all the parties to an appeal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party must file and serve a book of authorities at least 30 days before an appeal hearing date if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party's factum refers to an authority, or
the party intends to refer the court to an authority at the hearing of the appeal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subrule (2),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the parties to an appeal may file a joint book of authorities at least 30Â days before an appeal hearing date, and
filing a joint book of authorities under paragraph (a) satisfies the requirement for a party to file and serve a book of authorities.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A book of authorities and joint book of authorities must be prepared in accordance with the completion instructions.

If the registrar publishes a list of authorities, a party is not required to include an authority on that list in a book of authorities or joint book of authorities, unless the court or a justice will be asked to depart from or distinguish that authority.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Settling the contents of a document

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party may apply to the registrar to settle the contents of one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an appeal record;
a transcript;
an appeal book.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On application under subrule (1), the registrar may do one or more of the following in relation to a document referred to in that subrule:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: settle or limit the contents of the document;
direct that a party add or remove materials from the document;
direct that the document not be used in the appeal;
provide any other directions that may be required as a result of settling the contents of the document.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar may take an action under subrule (2) whether or not all parties attend the application hearing.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Additional Documents Filed to Ready a Cross Appeal for Hearing

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Not more than 30 days after being served an appellant's factum under RuleÂ 25Â (1), a respondent who has brought a cross appeal must file and serve a respondent's cross appeal factum instead of a respondent's factum under RuleÂ 25Â (2).
If an appellant is served a respondent's cross appeal factum, the appellant

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must file and serve an appellant's cross appeal response factum not more than 14Â days after being served, and
may file and serve an appellant's reply not more than 7 days after being served.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A respondent referred to in subrule (1) may reply to an appellant's cross appeal response factum by filing and serving a respondent's cross appeal reply not more than 7Â days after being served the appellant's cross appeal response factum.
A party must not unnecessarily repeat in a factum for a cross appeal any matters contained in a factum for the main appeal.
Documents filed under this rule must be prepared in accordance with the completion instructions.
In this rule, appeal book and joint appeal book have the same meaning as in RuleÂ 26.
If a respondent's cross appeal factum refers to evidence and that evidence is not included in the appellant's appeal book, the respondent

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must file and serve an appeal book when the respondent files and serves the respondent's cross appeal factum, or
may, instead of filing and serving an appeal book under paragraph (a), file a joint appeal book with the other parties not more than 30Â days after filing the respondent's cross appeal factum.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An appeal book and joint appeal book must be prepared in accordance with the completion instructions.
A party may request to expedite an appeal by doing the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: submitting a written request that meets the requirements set out in subrule (2) to the registrar;
serving on each party a copy of the written request,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A written request to expedite an appeal must succinctly state

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the nature of the appeal,
the reasons for the request,
whether the other parties consent to expediting the appeal,
the proposed terms for expediting the hearing of the appeal, including

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a schedule for the steps required to bring the appeal to hearing, and
an estimate of the time required for the hearing of the appeal, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a list of proposed dates for the hearing of the appeal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party may oppose a written request under subrule (1) by doing the following not more than 2 business days after being served the written request:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: submitting a written response to the registrar;
serving on each party a copy of the written response.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Steps After an Appeal Is Ready for Hearing

bcl:division.bcl:text: Appeals That Are Ready for Hearing

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: When an appeal is ready for hearing
bcl:section.bcl:text: An appeal is ready for hearing on

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the date the appellant has filed both

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the appellant's factum, and
a copy of each order being appealed, in the form that the order was entered in the court appealed from, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the date specified by a justice or the registrar as the date the appeal is ready for hearing.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Appellant must obtain appeal hearing date

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After an appeal is ready for hearing, an appellant must, without delay,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: obtain a hearing date for the appeal, and
inform the registrar if the parties disagree on the length of time required for the hearing of the appeal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After obtaining a hearing date under subrule (1), the appellant must, without delay, file and serve a notice of hearing of appeal in FormÂ 5 that has attached a copy of each order being appealed, in the form that the order was entered in the court appealed from.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Respondent may obtain appeal hearing date

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A respondent may obtain a hearing date for an appeal if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the respondent has filed a respondent's factum or respondent's cross appeal factum, and
the appellant has not complied with Rule 33 (1) or (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a respondent obtains a hearing date under subrule (1), the respondent must, not more thanÂ 5 days after obtaining the hearing date, file and serve a notice of hearing of appeal in FormÂ 5 that has attached a copy of each order being appealed, in the form that the order was entered in the court appealed from.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Registrar may set appeal hearing date

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar may set the date, time and place for the hearing of an appeal, subject to the directions of the chief justice.
On the request of the registrar, a party must, without delay, provide to the registrar an estimate of the time required for the hearing of an appeal.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Steps at the Hearing of an Appeal

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Points of law and authorities not cited in factum
bcl:section.bcl:text: The court, on terms it considers just, may permit a party to use arguments, raise points of law or cite authorities that were not used, raised or cited in the party's factum filed under PartÂ 4 [Steps After an Appeal Is Brought].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Condensed book of evidence and condensed book of authorities

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this rule:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: condensed book of authorities means a book that contains excerpts of authorities

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that are included in the party's filed book of authorities, and
that the party intends to refer the court to during the hearing of an appeal;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: condensed book of evidence means a book that contains documents

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that were filed in an appeal, and
that a party intends to refer the court to during the hearing of the appeal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party may submit a condensed book of authorities or a condensed book of evidence, or both, to the court at the hearing of an appeal by providing a copy of the condensed book to all of the following persons at the commencement of the hearing:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: each justice in the division of the court hearing the appeal;
each other party at the hearing of the appeal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subrule (2) does not apply in respect of a condensed book of authorities or condensed book of evidence if a filing directive requires the condensed book to be filed before the appeal hearing date.
A condensed book of authorities must be prepared in accordance with the completion instructions.
A condensed book of evidence

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must be prepared in accordance with the completion instructions, and
subject to subrule (6), may only include the following documents filed in the appeal:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: extracts of a transcript;
documents from the appeal record or appeal book.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Any extracts or documents included in a condensed book of evidence may include only as much material as is necessary to understand the context of the key portions of the extract or document.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Steps After an Appeal Has Been Heard

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Drawing up and entering the order of the court
bcl:section.bcl:text: After judgment on appeal has been given, the order of the court must be drawn up and entered in accordance with RuleÂ 66.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applying to registrar for assessment of costs

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After judgment on appeal has been given, a party who is entitled to costs may apply to the registrar for an assessment of costs under DivisionÂ 1 of PartÂ 11.

In bringing an application under subrule (1), a party must, in addition to complying with the requirements under RulesÂ 53 [application hearing date must be obtained] and 54 [notice of application], attach to the notice of application a bill of costs in FormÂ 21.

The registrar may order a party to give notice of an assessment of costs to a person whose interests could be affected by the assessment, including a person who has an interest in a fund or an estate.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applying to court for directions on costs

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: After judgment on appeal has been given, a party may apply to the court for directions under sectionÂ 45 [powers of court or a justice in relation to costs] of the Act if the parties disagree on matters in relation to costs.
To bring an application under subrule (1), a party must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: submit a written request to the registrar that includes

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a summary of the disagreement and the party's position on the disagreement, and
a proposed schedule for submissions by the parties or a request for the registrar to set a schedule for submissions by the parties, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: serve on each party a copy of the written request.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Dispensing with a rule or extending a time limit
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person may apply to a justice to do one or more of the following under sectionÂ 32 [dispensing with rules and varying time limits] of the Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: dispense with a requirement of these rules;
extend the time limit provided in these rules for doing an act.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The court, a justice or the registrar may allow a person to attend a hearing or case management by telephone, video conference or other means of telecommunication authorized by the chief justice.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Having appeal heard by more than 3 justices

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party may request that an appeal be heard by more than 3 justices by doing the following at least 6Â weeks before the appeal hearing date:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: submitting a written request stating the reasons for the request to the registrar;
serving on each party a copy of the written request.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party may oppose a written request under subrule (1) by doing the following not more than 5 days after being served the written request:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: submitting a written response to the registrar;
serving on each party a copy of the written response.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party to an appeal may apply to the court or a justice to cross-examine a deponent of an affidavit filed in relation to the appeal by another party or an intervener.
On application under subrule (1), the court or a justice may order that the deponent attend for cross-examination before a commissioner for taking affidavits specified by the court or justice.
A cross-examination of a deponent must occur before the hearing of the appeal or application for which the deponent's affidavit was filed.
A party must notify the registrar without delay if, after a hearing date has been set for an appeal or application,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party wishes to adjourn the appeal, or
all the parties agree that the appeal should be adjourned.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party who wishes to adjourn an appeal during the 3 weeks before the appeal hearing date must submit a written request for the adjournment to the registrar.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Abandoning an appeal or application for leave to appeal
bcl:section.bcl:text: If an appeal or application for leave to appeal is abandoned, because of settlement or for any other reason, the appellant must, without delay, file and serve a notice of settlement or abandonment in FormÂ 6.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party may request that an appeal be referred to case management by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: submitting a written request to the registrar, and
serving on each party a copy of the written request.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A justice or the registrar may, on request of a party or on the justice's or registrar's own initiative, do one or both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: direct that the parties attend case management before a justice or the registrar, either

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in person, or
by telephone, video conference or other means of telecommunication authorized by the chief justice;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: direct that case management be conducted in writing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party must participate in case management as directed under subrule (2).
Despite subrule (3), a party is not required to attend case management before a justice or the registrar if the party's lawyer attends.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Powers of a justice on case management

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: During case management for an appeal, a justice may make orders or give directions, with or without a party making an application, for the purposes of managing the conduct of the appeal, including the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: simplifying or isolating issues on appeal;
setting the time for the hearing of the appeal;
setting a schedule for the steps required to bring the appeal to hearing;
requiring that 2 or more appeals be heard together;
permitting substitutional service;
allowing a factum to include additional pages;
requiring that monies be paid in and out of court;
amending, in any manner, any documents filed in the court;
granting permission to hear an application on shorter notice than otherwise required under these rules;
granting cross-examination on an affidavit;
settling the contents of an appeal record, appeal book or transcript.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: During case management, a justice or the registrar may refer a matter to be heard by the court or a justice in chambers if the justice or registrar considers it to be in the interests of justice.
The registrar must, in accordance with this Division, maintain a list of appeals that are inactive.
If an appeal is on the inactive appeal list during a period, any application for leave to appeal that relates to the appeal is deemed to be on the inactive appeal list during that period.

An appellant may not file any document in relation to an appeal or application for leave to appeal that is on the inactive appeal list unless the document relates to an application for leave to proceed with the appeal.
The registrar must place an appeal on the inactive appeal list if a notice of hearing of appeal is not filed in accordance with these rules by the date that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: one year after the notice of appeal is filed for the appeal, or
60 days after the appeal is ready for hearing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Other than a consent order or application to reactivate the appeal, the registrar may not accept filings for an appeal that is on the inactive appeal list.
The registrar must remove an appeal from the inactive appeal list if a justice grants leave to proceed with the appeal.
The registrar must return an appeal to the inactive appeal list if either of the following occurs:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a party fails to comply with the terms or conditions imposed, or directions given, by a justice in an order granting leave to proceed under subruleÂ (3);
a notice of hearing of appeal is not yet filed more than 180 days after a justice grants leave to proceed under subruleÂ (3).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the registrar places an appeal on or returns an appeal to the inactive appeal list, the registrar must provide notice to each party to the appeal who has provided an address for service.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Appeals that are dismissed as abandoned

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 23 [appeals or applications for leave to appeal dismissed as abandoned] of the Act, an appeal or application for leave to appeal is dismissed as abandoned if it remains on the inactive appeal list for 180Â days.
Unless a justice orders otherwise, an appeal that is dismissed as abandoned under subrule (1) may not be reinstated.

bcl:division.bcl:text: How to Bring and Respond to Applications Made to the Court, a Justice or the Registrar

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Applications made to the court, a justice or the registrar

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subrule (2), this Division applies to every application made to the court, a justice or the registrar.
This Division does not apply to the following applications:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an application for leave to appeal under Rule 13 [how to apply for leave to appeal];
an application to be added as a respondent under Rule 18 [justice may add respondents to an appeal];
an application for a stay of proceedings or stay of execution under Rule 20 [applying for a stay of proceedings or execution];
an application referred to in Division 2 of this Part;
an application to the registrar to settle an order under Rule 68 [settling the form or content of orders];
an application for an order that no fees are payable under Rule 85 [order that no fees payable].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application hearing date must be obtained
bcl:section.bcl:text: Before filing a notice of application or any other document for the purposes of commencing an application, a person who wishes to bring an application must obtain a hearing date for the application.
A person who wishes to bring an application must file and serve the following documents at least 5 business days before the application hearing date:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a notice of application in Form 4;
the person's supporting affidavits, if any;
the person's written argument, if any.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who is served a notice of application may, for the purposes of responding to the application, file and serve the following documents at least 2 business days before the application hearing date:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person's supporting affidavits, if any;
the person's written argument, if any.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Registrar may set chambers application hearing date
bcl:section.bcl:text: The registrar may set the date, time and place for the hearing of a chambers application under these rules.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Specific Requirements for Bringing and Responding to Certain Applications

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this rule, urgent application means an application made under subruleÂ (2) for permission to bring another application on shorter notice.
In case of urgency, a person may apply for permission to bring an application on shorter notice than otherwise required under these rules by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: obtaining a hearing date for the application, and
filing an urgent application in Form 7.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On an urgent application, a justice or the registrar may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: order that an application be heard on shorter notice than otherwise required under these rules, including

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: setting the date for hearing the application, and
setting the date by which documents in relation to the application must be filed and served;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: impose conditions or give directions related to the urgent application.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 240/2023, s. 3 (b).]
A party who wishes to apply for an order for payment into court of security under section 34 [payment of security] of the Act must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: obtain a hearing date for the application, and
file and serve a notice of application in Form 4 and an application book prepared in accordance with the completion instructions at least 5 business days before the application hearing date.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party who is served an application referred to in subrule (1) may, for the purposes of responding to the application, file and serve, at least 2Â business days before the application hearing date, a response book prepared in accordance with the completion instructions.
A party who wishes to apply for leave to adduce evidence that was not before the court appealed from must, at least 30 days before the appeal hearing date, file and serve the following documents:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a notice of application in Form 4;
a supporting affidavit that includes the evidence that the party is seeking to adduce;
the party's other supporting affidavits, if any;
the party's written argument, if any, that sets out why the party should be permitted to adduce the evidence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party who is served an application referred to in subrule (1) may, for the purposes of responding to the application, file and serve the following documents at least 7Â business days before the application hearing date:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party's supporting affidavits, if any;
the party's written argument, if any.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless a justice or the registrar orders otherwise, an application brought under this rule must be heard at the time of the hearing of the appeal by the division of the court hearing the appeal.

For certainty, a party's factum under Rule 25 or 29 may refer to evidence that was not before the court appealed from even though an application under this rule about whether the evidence may be adduced has not yet been heard.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Quashing an appeal or raising a preliminary objection

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This rule applies to an application to do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: strike part of a factum;
raise a preliminary objection to an appeal;
quash an appeal before it is heard.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party who wishes to apply to do anything referred to in subrule (1) must, at least 7 business days before the application hearing date, file and serve the following documents:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a notice of application in Form 4;
the party's supporting affidavits, if any;
the party's written argument, if any.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party who is served an application referred to in subrule (2) may, for the purposes of responding to the application, file and serve the following documents at least 2Â business days before the application hearing date:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party's supporting affidavits, if any;
the party's written argument, if any.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless a justice or the registrar orders otherwise, an application under this rule must be heard at the time of the hearing of the appeal.
A person, other than a party, interested in an appeal may apply to a justice for leave to intervene in the appeal.
To apply for leave to intervene in an appeal, a person must do the following no later than 14Â days after the appellant files the appellant's factum:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: obtain a hearing date for the application;
file and serve the following documents:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a notice of application in Form 4;
the person's supporting affidavits, if any;
a memorandum of argument prepared in accordance with the completion instructions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who is served an application referred to in subrule (2) may, for the purposes of responding to the application, file and serve on each party and on the applicant, at least 2 business days before the application hearing date, the following documents:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person's supporting affidavits, if any;
the person's written argument, if any.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In making an order granting leave to intervene, a justice

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must specify the date on which the intervener's factum is due, and
may make any other order the justice considers appropriate to accommodate the intervener's participation in an appeal, including

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: limiting the issues on which the intervener may intervene,
requiring the parties to serve documents on the intervener as if the intervener were a party, or
requiring the intervener to pay additional costs incurred by any party as a result of the intervention.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless a justice orders otherwise, an intervener's factum

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must be prepared in accordance with the completion instructions, and
must not exceed 10 pages.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An intervener may not present oral argument during the hearing of an appeal, unless a justice orders otherwise.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Varying or cancelling an order of a justice

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition to an order referred to in section 29 (2) (a) [varying orders of a justice] of the Act, the following are prescribed under sectionÂ 29 of the Act as orders that may not be varied:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order or direction under Rule 48 (1) granting or refusing relief in a case management conference;
an order for shorter notice in bringing an application than otherwise required under these rules;
an order to expedite an appeal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who wishes to apply to have the court, under section 29 of the Act, vary or cancel an order other than an order referred to in subruleÂ (1) must do the following not more than 7Â days after the order is made:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: obtain a hearing date for the application;
file and serve a notice of application to vary or cancel an order of a justice in FormÂ 8.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who files a notice of application under subrule (2) must, not more than 14Â days after filing the notice of application, file and serve an application book prepared in accordance with the completion instructions.

A person who wishes to respond to an application book filed under subruleÂ (3) must file and serve, on the applicant and on each party not more than 7Â days after being served the application book, a response book prepared in accordance with the completion instructions.
The date, time and place for the hearing of an application under this rule must be set by the registrar.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Varying or cancelling an order of the registrar

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this rule, order includes a certificate of costs issued by the registrar.
A person who wishes to apply to have a justice, under section 35 [varying orders of a justice or registrar] of the Act, vary or cancel an order or direction of the registrar must do the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: no later than 7 days after the order was made or direction given, obtain a hearing date for the application;
at least 5 business days before the application hearing date, file and serve the following documents:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a notice of application in Form 4;
the person's supporting affidavits, if any;
the person's written argument, if any.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who is served a notice of application referred to in subruleÂ (2) may, for the purposes of responding to the application, file and serve the following documents at least 2Â business days before the application hearing date:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person's supporting affidavits, if any;
the person's written argument, if any.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this Division, party, in relation to an application, means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person who brings the application in accordance with these rules, and
a person who is served the notice of application in relation to the application in accordance with these rules.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subrule (3), this Division applies to every application made to the court, a justice or the registrar.
This Division does not apply to the following applications:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an application to the registrar under Rule 68 to settle an order;
an application for an order that no fees are payable under RuleÂ 85.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Each party to an application must attend the hearing of the application

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in person, or
if permitted under Rule 42 [attendance through telecommunications], by telephone, video conference or other means of telecommunication.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subrule (1), a party to an application is not required to attend the hearing of an application if the person's lawyer attends.
Before the hearing date of an application,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person bringing the application may seek to adjourn the hearing by filing a requisition in accordance with this rule, or
with the consent of the person bringing the application, a person responding to the application may seek to adjourn the hearing by filing a requisition in accordance with this rule.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A requisition referred to in subrule (1) must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: completed in Form 9, and
filed before 2 p.m. on the business day before the application hearing date.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless a justice or the registrar directs otherwise, an application stands adjourned if a requisition in respect of the application is filed in accordance with subrulesÂ (1) andÂ (2).
For certainty, if an application does not stand adjourned under subruleÂ (3),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the parties to the application must attend the hearing of the application, and
a party to the application may request an adjournment at that hearing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the hearing of an application is adjourned under this rule without setting a new application hearing date, the person bringing the application may set a new application hearing date by filing and serving, at least 5Â business days before the new application hearing date, a requisition in FormÂ 9 setting out the new hearing date and time.
An order of the court or a justice must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: drawn up in the form required under subrule (3),
dated as of the date the order is pronounced,
approved in writing by each party or lawyer of record, unless the court, a justice or the registrar directs otherwise, and
submitted to the court and entered after it is completed and approved in accordance with paragraphsÂ (a) toÂ (c) of this subrule.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of subrule (1) (a), an order may be drawn up by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a party who attended the hearing,
a lawyer who attended the hearing, or
the registrar, if and as directed by the court or a justice.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An order must be in the following form:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of an order of a justice, Form 10;
in the case of an order resulting from a decision made by 3 or more justices, FormÂ 11;
in the case of an order resulting from an application to vary or cancel an order of a justice, FormÂ 12.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar must keep all entered orders, in accordance with any directions given by the chief justice.
A consent order must not be entered unless the consent of each party affected by the order is demonstrated by the party or the party's lawyer

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: orally before the court, a justice or the registrar, or
in writing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party seeking one of the following consent orders must file a draft of the order in the following form:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of an order to extend the time to file a document, Form 13;
in the case of an order to remove from the inactive appeal list an appeal that has not already been removed from the inactive appeal list, Form 14;
in the case of any other consent order, Form 15.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Settling the form or content of orders

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the parties to an appeal do not agree on the form or content of an order, the parties must apply to the registrar to settle the order.
On application under subrule (1), the registrar may settle the form or content of an order, with or without a hearing and whether or not all parties attend the application hearing.
The registrar may refer a draft order to the division of the court or the justice who made the order.
In this rule, unit is a number representing an amount of time that would ordinarily be spent on a matter, as set out in the ordinary costs tariff.
Ordinary costs payable to a party must be assessed in accordance with this rule, regardless of whether those costs are payable

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by another party,
out of a fund of other parties, or
out of a fund in which the party whose costs are being assessed has a common interest with other persons.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On an assessment of ordinary costs for a proceeding, the registrar must allow each unit in each item in the ordinary costs tariff that the registrar determines was proper or reasonably necessary to conduct the proceeding.

For certainty, on an assessment of ordinary costs for a proceeding, the registrar must disallow any items in the ordinary costs tariff that were not proper or reasonably necessary to conduct the proceeding.
If a maximum and minimum number of units are provided in an item in the ordinary costs tariff, the registrar may allow only a number of units in the item within that range.
In making an allowance under subrule (5), the registrar must have regard to the following principles:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the minimum number of units in a range is for matters on which little time should ordinarily be spent;
the maximum number of units in a range is for matters on which a great deal of time should ordinarily be spent.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The value for each unit allowed on an assessment of ordinary costs is as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of scale A, $110;
in the case of scale B, $170.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Ordinary costs must be assessed under scale A, unless a justice orders that ordinary costs be assessed under scaleÂ B.
In fixing the scale of ordinary costs, a justice

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must consider the following principles:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: scale A is for matters of ordinary complexity;
scale B is for matters of unusual complexity or importance, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may consider the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: whether a difficult issue of law, fact or construction is involved;
whether an issue is of importance to a class or body of persons, or is of general interest.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At any time before the costs for an appeal are assessed, a justice may order costs to be assessed as increased costs if the justice determines that assessment under the ordinary cost tariff would create an unjust result.
If costs are ordered to be assessed as increased costs, the registrar must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: fix the fees that would have been allowed if an order for special costs had been made under RuleÂ 71Â (1), and
allow as costs

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: half of those fees, or
a different proportion of those fees, as ordered by the court or a justice.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A justice may order that costs be assessed as special costs.
If costs for a proceeding are ordered to be assessed as special costs, the registrar must allow each fee that the registrar determines was proper or reasonably necessary to conduct the proceeding.
In making a determination under subrule (2), the registrar must consider all of the circumstances, including the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the complexity of the proceeding;
the difficulty or novelty of the matters involved;
the amount involved in the proceeding;
the time reasonably spent in conducting the proceeding;
the importance of the proceeding, or of the result obtained, to the party whose costs are being assessed;
the benefit, to the party whose costs are being assessed, of the services rendered by the party's lawyer;
the skill, specialized knowledge and responsibility required of the lawyer of the party whose costs are being assessed;
any party's conduct that tended to shorten or unnecessarily lengthen the duration of the proceeding.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party may render a bill for special costs as a lump sum.
A bill for special costs rendered as a lump sum must include the following information in sufficient detail for a lawyer to advise a client about the reasonableness of the charges made:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a description of the nature of the services rendered;
a description of the matters involved.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party to an assessment of a bill for special costs, or a review of a lump sum bill for special costs, may submit as evidence an opinion of a lawyer respecting

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the nature and importance of the services rendered,
the matters involved, and
the reasonableness of the charges made.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party must not submit the opinions of more than 2 lawyers under subruleÂ (6).
The registrar may require a lawyer giving an opinion under subruleÂ (6) to attend an assessment for examination or cross-examination.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Assessment of fees, disbursements and expenses

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In addition to the costs assessed for a proceeding, the registrar must allow a reasonable amount for disbursements and expenses that were necessary or properly incurred in the conduct of the proceeding.
If tax is payable by a party in respect of legal services, the tax must be included in the total of any assessed fees or disbursements.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Costs for preparation for activities that do not take place
bcl:section.bcl:text: The registrar may allow units set out in the ordinary costs tariff, up to the maximum number allowable, for the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: preparation of documents that are not ultimately used in a proceeding;
preparation for an application, conference or hearing that does not ultimately take place or is adjourned.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a party is entitled to receive costs from and liable to pay costs to another party, the registrar may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: assess the costs each party is liable to pay;
adjust the costs by way of reduction or set-off;
delay the allowance of the costs that a party is entitled to receive until the party has paid or tendered the costs that the party is liable to pay.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the costs claimed by a party against a second party should be paid by a third party, the registrar may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: order that payment be made to the first party directly by the third party;
order the second party to pay the costs to the first party and allow the second party to claim that payment as a disbursement against the third party;
make any other order the registrar considers appropriate to reapportion costs between the parties.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar may take action under subrule (2) if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: 2 or more appeals have, by order, been heard at the same time or one after another, and
no order has been made to apportion costs of the appeals.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the circumstances referred to in subrule (1), the registrar may do one or more of the following in relation to the appeals:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: assess 2 or more bills of costs as a single bill of costs;
allow an item in a bill of costs more than once;
apportion the costs of an item in a bill of costs, or the entire bill of costs, between the appeals.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before the registrar makes an assessment of costs, a party may serve on another party, in FormÂ 16, an offer to settle the amount of a bill of costs.
At the conclusion of a hearing on the assessment of costs, a party may submit to the registrar an offer to settle that was served under subruleÂ (1).
The registrar may do one or more of the following if the registrar determines that an offer to settle should have been accepted:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the offer to settle was made by the party whose costs were assessed, allow twice the value of an item in the ordinary costs tariff, or of a fee, that relates to the assessment;
if the offer to settle was rejected by the party whose costs were assessed,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: disallow to that party an item in the ordinary costs tariff, or a disbursement, that relates to the assessment, or
allow by way of set-off, to the party who made the offer to settle, an item in the ordinary costs tariff, or a disbursement, that relates to the assessment;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: fix an amount of costs that the registrar considers reasonable in the circumstances.

bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 46 (2) [powers of registrar in relation to costs] of the Act, the registrar must issue a certificate of costs in FormÂ 17

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on the conclusion of an assessment of costs, or
if the party liable to pay costs has consented to the assessed amount.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a justice determines that a party's lawyer caused costs to be incurred without reasonable cause or to be wasted through delay, neglect or some other fault, the justice may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: disallow any fees and disbursements between the lawyer and the party;
if fees or disbursements have been paid by the party to the lawyer, order the lawyer to repay all or part of them to the party;
order the lawyer to indemnify the party for all or part of any costs that the party has been ordered to pay to another party;
make any other order that the justice considers appropriate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a justice makes an order under subrule (1), the justice may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: direct the registrar to conduct an inquiry and file a report with recommendations as to the amount of costs, or
fix the costs, with or without reference to the ordinary costs tariff.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A justice may not make an order under this rule against a lawyer unless the lawyer is present or has been given notice.

A lawyer against whom an order has been made under this rule must promptly deliver a copy of the order to the party represented by the lawyer, whether or not the lawyer continues to represent the party.
In this rule, court form means a document that is required under these rules to be filed using a specified form.
All documents filed in a court registry, or otherwise submitted to the court, must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in English, and
if the document is in paper form, legibly printed or typewritten on durable white paper having dimensions of 21.5Â cm by 28Â cm.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A court form must be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prepared and filed using the specified form set out in Schedule 3, with variations as the circumstances or the proceedings require, and
completed in accordance with any instructions included on the court form.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless otherwise provided in another enactment, these rules or a court form,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: handwritten signatures are not required on documents filed in a court registry, or otherwise submitted to the court, and
documents submitted for filing must contain the name of the person authorizing the filing of the document.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar may refuse to accept a document for filing if the document does not comply with these rules.
A document that is received for filing electronically may be treated by the registrar for all purposes as an original document.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Parties must have address for service

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Each party may have an email address for service and must have one of the following addresses for service:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the office address in British Columbia of the party's lawyer of record;
a residential address or business address in British Columbia, other than a post office box;
if permitted by a justice or the registrar, a residential address or business address outside of British Columbia, other than a post office box;
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 240/2023, s. 9 (b).]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party must include the party's address for service and, if any, the party's email address for service, on the following that is filed on behalf of the party:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a notice of appeal;
a form under these rules that requires the address for service be included.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party who wishes to apply for permission under subrule (1) (c) to use a residential address or business address for service outside of British Columbia must submit a written request to the registrar.
This rule applies to the following applications:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an application to set aside the consequences of default;
an application for an extension of time;
an application in support of a request for an adjournment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Even though a document has been served in accordance with Rule 4, a person may show, on an application referred to in subruleÂ (1), that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the document did not come to the person's notice,
the document did come to the person's notice, but later than when it was served or effectively served, or
the document was incomplete or illegible.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subrules (2), (3) and (4), a document that has been filed with the court may be amended by a person only with the consent of all the parties or the permission of the court, a justice or the registrar.
An appellant may file and serve an amended notice of appeal without the consent of the parties or the permission of the court, a justice or the registrar as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an appellant who is not required to apply for leave to appeal may amend a notice of appeal before filing the appellant's factum;
an appellant who is required to apply for leave to appeal may amend a notice of appeal before filing, as applicable,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the related application book for leave to appeal, or
the related application book for leave to appeal and stay.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A respondent may file and serve an amended notice of cross appeal without the consent of the parties or the permission of the court, a justice or the registrar as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a respondent who is not required to apply for leave to appeal may amend a notice of cross appeal before filing the respondent's cross appeal factum;
a respondent who is required to apply for leave to appeal may amend a notice of cross appeal before filing, as applicable,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the related application book for leave to appeal, or
the related application book for leave to appeal and stay.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party may, at least 4 weeks before the appeal hearing date, file and serve an amended factum without the permission of the court, a justice or the registrar if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party changes lawyers, or discharges a lawyer in order to act on the party's own behalf, and
all the parties consent to the amended factum being filed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party may file and serve an amended factum during the 4 weeks before the appeal hearing date only with the permission of the court, a justice or the registrar.
Unless otherwise directed by the court, a justice or the registrar, a party who is served an amended factum must file and serve an amended response factum not more than 15 days after being served.
For the purposes of subrule (6), the amendments in an amended response factum may address only the amendments made in the amended factum.
Unless the registrar directs otherwise, each court registry must be kept open to the public between 9Â a.m and 4Â p.m. on each day other than a Saturday or a holiday.
The registrar must provide reasonable notice to the public of a direction referred to in subruleÂ (1).
A document submitted for filing to a court registry and accepted for filing by the registrar is deemed to be filed as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the document is submitted at or before 4 p.m. on a business day, the document is deemed to be filed on that day;
if the document is submitted at either of the following times, the document is deemed to be filed on the next business day:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: after 4 p.m. on a business day;
any time on a day other than a business day.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A document transmitted for filing electronically is deemed to be submitted when it is transmitted.
In this rule, table of fees means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the table of fees in Division 1 of Schedule 2, or
if an amended table of fees is published by the Registrar of Regulations under DivisionÂ 2 of ScheduleÂ 2, the most recently published amended table.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For any matter described in column 1 of the table of fees, the fee set out opposite in column 2 must be paid to the government.
The fees in the table of fees must be recalculated at the frequency set out in, and in accordance with, DivisionÂ 2 of ScheduleÂ 2.
A person may apply for an order that no fees are payable under RuleÂ 84 by filing a FormÂ 22, which is to be considered an application if a hearing date is set under subruleÂ (2).
If the registrar determines that a hearing is required, the registrar may set a date for the hearing of the application.
The hearing of an application under this rule is to proceed without notice.
At the hearing of an application under this rule, a justice may order that no fees are payable if the justice finds that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the appeal is not

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: bound to fail,
scandalous, frivolous or vexatious, or
an abuse of the process of the court, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person's payment of court fees under Rule 84 would cause undue hardship.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A finding under subrule (4) (a) does not bind a justice in any other applications on the appeal.
For the purposes of this rule, the registrar may identify financial circumstances in which the payment of court fees under RuleÂ 84 would cause undue hardship.
A person who is not represented by a lawyer in an appeal may appoint a lawyer to act for the person by filing a notice of change of representation or change of address for service in FormÂ 18.
A person who is represented by a lawyer in an appeal may do either of the following by filing a notice of change of representation or change of address for service in FormÂ 18:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: change to a different lawyer;
discharge the lawyer and act on the person's own behalf.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A lawyer who ceases to act for a person may withdraw from an appeal by filing and serving a notice of withdrawal of lawyer in FormÂ 19.
A person who is served notice under subrule (1) may object to the withdrawal by filing and serving an objection in FormÂ 20 not more than 7Â days after being served.

If an objection is filed under subrule (2), the lawyer who filed the notice may apply to a justice for a declaration that the lawyer has ceased to be lawyer of record for the person to whom the notice relates.
An application referred to in subrule (3) must be served on the person who filed the objection under subruleÂ (2).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: When a lawyer is the lawyer of record

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A lawyer appointed by a person's notice of change of representation or change of address for service filed under RuleÂ 86 is the person's lawyer of record.
A lawyer ceases to be a person's lawyer of record when any of the following occurs:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person files a notice under Rule 86 (2) for the purposes of changing lawyers or discharging the lawyer;
the lawyer files and serves a notice under Rule 87 (1) and no objection is made under RuleÂ 87Â (2);
the court declares that the lawyer has ceased to be the person's lawyer of record.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may serve documents on a lawyer as another person's lawyer of record until that lawyer ceases to be the other person's lawyer of record under subruleÂ (2).

bcl:section.bcl:text: The court may issue practice directives to regulate and control its procedure.
In this Part:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: effective date means the date that this rule comes into force;
former rules means the Court of Appeal Rules, B.C. Reg.Â 297/2001, as they read immediately before the effective date;
pre-existing appeal means either of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an appeal that was commenced before the effective date;
an appeal that relates to a pre-existing application for leave to appeal;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: pre-existing application for leave to appeal means an application for leave to appeal that was commenced before the effective date;
pre-existing cross appeal means a cross appeal that was commenced before the effective date.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application of rules to pre-existing appeals and applications for leave to appeal

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as otherwise provided in this Part, these rules apply to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a pre-existing appeal, or
a pre-existing application for leave to appeal.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following rules do not apply to a pre-existing appeal or pre-existing application for leave to appeal:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Rule 11 (a) (i) and (x) and (b) (i) and (v) [limited appeal orders];
Rule 29 (5) [factums on cross appeal];
Rule 69 [assessment of ordinary costs].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Bringing cross appeals in relation to pre-existing applications for leave to appeal
bcl:section.bcl:text: A respondent who has been served an order granting leave to appeal in relation to a pre-existing application for leave to appeal may bring a cross appeal by complying with Rule 9 and, for that purpose, "a notice of appeal" in Rule 9 must be read as "an order granting leave to appeal in relation to a pre-existing application for leave to appeal".

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Ordinary costs in relation to pre-existing appeals
bcl:section.bcl:text: Ordinary costs in relation to a pre-existing appeal must be assessed in accordance with Appendix B of the former rules.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Page limits for cross appeal factums and replies
bcl:section.bcl:text: Documents filed under Rule 29 [factums on cross appeal] in relation to a pre-existing cross appeal must be prepared in accordance with the completion instructions and as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a respondent's cross appeal factum must not exceed 40Â pages;
an appellant's cross appeal response factum must not exceed 30Â pages;
an appellant's reply must not exceed 5Â pages;
a respondent's cross appeal reply must not exceed 5 pages.
